thisisnic commented on code in PR #13118:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/13118#discussion_r871237912


##########
r/R/dplyr-funcs-datetime.R:
##########
@@ -518,6 +518,28 @@ register_bindings_datetime_parsers <- function() {
 
     coalesce_output <- build_expr("coalesce", args = parse_attempt_expressions)
 
-    build_expr("assume_timezone", coalesce_output, options = list(timezone = tz))
+    if (!is.null(tz)) {

Review Comment:
   Please can you add a brief comment about why we need this logic here?



##########
r/R/dplyr-funcs-datetime.R:
##########
@@ -518,6 +518,28 @@ register_bindings_datetime_parsers <- function() {
 
     coalesce_output <- build_expr("coalesce", args = parse_attempt_expressions)
 
-    build_expr("assume_timezone", coalesce_output, options = list(timezone = tz))
+    if (!is.null(tz)) {
+      build_expr("assume_timezone", coalesce_output, options = list(timezone = tz))
+    } else {
+      coalesce_output
+    }
+
   })
+
+  ymd_parser_vec <- c("ymd", "ydm", "mdy", "myd", "dmy", "dym")
+
+  ymd_parser_map_factory <- function(order) {
+    force(order)

Review Comment:
   Why do we need to call `force()` here?



##########
r/R/dplyr-funcs-datetime.R:
##########
@@ -518,6 +518,28 @@ register_bindings_datetime_parsers <- function() {
 
     coalesce_output <- build_expr("coalesce", args = parse_attempt_expressions)
 
-    build_expr("assume_timezone", coalesce_output, options = list(timezone = tz))
+    if (!is.null(tz)) {
+      build_expr("assume_timezone", coalesce_output, options = list(timezone = tz))
+    } else {
+      coalesce_output
+    }
+
   })
+
+  ymd_parser_vec <- c("ymd", "ydm", "mdy", "myd", "dmy", "dym")
+
+  ymd_parser_map_factory <- function(order) {
+    force(order)
+    function(x, tz = NULL) {
+      parse_x <- call_binding("parse_date_time", x, order, tz)
+      if (is.null(tz)) {
+        parse_x <- parse_x$cast(date32())

Review Comment:
   Again, just needs a brief comment here about why we have to cast in this case.

URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/13118#discussion_r871271328


##########

##########
@@ -518,6 +518,28 @@ register_bindings_datetime_parsers <- function() {
 
     coalesce_output <- build_expr("coalesce", args = parse_attempt_expressions)
 
-    build_expr("assume_timezone", coalesce_output, options = list(timezone = tz))
+    if (!is.null(tz)) {

+
+  ymd_parser_map_factory <- function(order) {
+    force(order)

Review Comment:
   This is the key bit from Advanced R: 
   > Unfortunately it doesn’t because x is only evaluated lazily when square() is run, not when power1() is run. In general, this problem will arise whenever a binding changes in between calling the factory function and calling the manufactured function. This is likely to only happen rarely, but when it does, it will lead to a real head-scratcher of a bug.
   >
   > We can fix this problem by forcing evaluation with [force()](https://rdrr.io/r/base/force.html):

thisisnic commented on code in PR #13118:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/13118#discussion_r871271816


##########
r/tests/testthat/test-dplyr-funcs-datetime.R:
##########
@@ -1732,3 +1732,44 @@ test_that("parse_date_time() doesn't work with hour, minutes, and second compone
     '"ymd_HMS" `orders` not supported in Arrow'
   )
 })
+
+test_that("year, month, day date/time parsers work", {
+  test_df <- tibble::tibble(
+    ymd_string = c("2022-05-11", "2022/05/12", "22.05-13"),
+    ydm_string = c("2022-11-05", "2022/12/05", "22.13-05"),
+    mdy_string = c("05-11-2022", "05/12/2022", "05.13-22"),
+    myd_string = c("05-2022-11", "05/2022/12", "05.22-14"),
+    dmy_string = c("11-05-2022", "12/05/2022", "13.05-22"),
+    dym_string = c("11-2022-05", "12/2022/05", "13.22-05")
+  )
+
+  # string processing requires RE2 library (not available on Windows with R 3.6)

Review Comment:
   My immediate reaction: but this isn't string processing, this is datetime processing!
   
   ```suggestion
     # these functions' internals use some string processing which requires RE2 library (not available on Windows with R 3.6)
   ```

dragosmg commented on code in PR #13118:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/13118#discussion_r871275011


##########
r/tests/testthat/test-dplyr-funcs-datetime.R:
##########
@@ -1732,3 +1732,44 @@ test_that("parse_date_time() doesn't work with hour, minutes, and second compone
     '"ymd_HMS" `orders` not supported in Arrow'
   )
 })
+
+test_that("year, month, day date/time parsers work", {
+  test_df <- tibble::tibble(
+    ymd_string = c("2022-05-11", "2022/05/12", "22.05-13"),
+    ydm_string = c("2022-11-05", "2022/12/05", "22.13-05"),
+    mdy_string = c("05-11-2022", "05/12/2022", "05.13-22"),
+    myd_string = c("05-2022-11", "05/2022/12", "05.22-14"),
+    dmy_string = c("11-05-2022", "12/05/2022", "13.05-22"),
+    dym_string = c("11-2022-05", "12/2022/05", "13.22-05")
+  )
+
+  # string processing requires RE2 library (not available on Windows with R 3.6)

Review Comment:
   We're parsing a string into a date or a date/time. Some string processing takes place before a call to `strptime()`.

issuetype.description: A new feature of the product, which has yet to be developed.
issuetype.name: New Feature

fields.description:
Parse dates with year, month, and day components:
ymd() ydm() mdy() myd() dmy() dym()
fields.summary: [R] Implement lubridate's parsers with year, month and date components
